linkTarget.anchoringText: In an effort to make strong multivariate models, and compare wells with similar geology, five DJ Basin study areas were defined, as shown in Figure 7. Boundaries were defined using several key pieces of data, including gas-oil ratio (GOR), oil gravity, and spatial distribution of wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: General DJ Basin overview showing multivariate study boundaries and horizontal well locations.

formatted-caption.caption-text: General DJ Basin overview showing multivariate study boundaries and horizontal well locations.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This sparse data set does not lend itself to a rigorous multivariate statistical analysis, and therefore is not included in any production or cost sensitivity modeling. Despite the small data set, simple bivariate analyses are still valid, and valuable insight can be gleaned from them. Figure 8 shows two bivariate plots looking at completion parameters versus 365-day production. There are clear trends, with strong R2 values, that show a positive impact on production for both increased proppant amounts and frac fluid volumes.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Bi-variate plots of completion parameters versus 365-day production in the Southern DJ study area.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Bi-variate plots of completion parameters versus 365-day production in the Southern DJ study area.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The multivariate results for one example study, the Niobrara in NE Weld County, are shown in Figure 9. The production model uses a total of six parameters. Three are driven by the completion design (stage intensity, frac fluid volume and average proppant concentration) and three are related to reservoir quality (TVD, HPV, and water cut). The tables in Figure 9 show the relative sensitivity of each parameter – for example, a 42% reduction in stage spacing from the dataset average of 217 ft down to 125 ft increases production by 17%.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: 180-day cumulative production sensitivities to completion and petrophysical parameters for Niobrara wells in NE Weld County. Red colors indicates predictions in areas beyond 2 standard deviations from the dataset; and green represent the averages for the dataset.

formatted-caption.caption-text: 180-day cumulative production sensitivities to completion and petrophysical parameters for Niobrara wells in NE Weld County. Red colors indicates predictions in areas beyond 2 standard deviations from the dataset; and green represent the averages for the dataset.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The multivariate results for the remaining four study areas are presented in table format in Figure 10, which shows the production sensitivity of all independent completion and petrophysical parameters. As such, each column represents a simple linear regression model that can be used to forecast production. For example, 365-day cumulative production in the Inner Core Wattenberg Niobrara increases by 0.009 boe/ft for every lbs/ft increase, while a 1% increase in water cut reduces production after 365 days by 0.28 boe/ft.

image-wrap.caption: Production sensitivities to completion parameters for all study areas.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 12 shows the typical cost for all these areas to increase 365-day or 180-day production by 10%. The results in the table shows that there are no _silver bullets_ for the most economic production improvements in the DJ Basin – the solution to improve production in the best possible way is not the same everywhere. In Inner Core Wattenberg, the better and higher GOR wells in the DJ Basin are helped more by placing more proppant. This focus on conductivity may also indicate that higher-quality proppant might do better in this area.
